key_insight: AndroidLens introduces a large-scale, bilingual benchmark of 571 realistic, long-latency Android GUI tasks (average >26 steps) with nested sub-targets and fine-grained evaluation, enabling realistic assessment of GUI agents' long-horizon capabilities.
problem_solved: Existing GUI-agent evaluations are limited to few apps, short/simple tasks, and coarse metrics; AndroidLens fills this gap by providing challenging, multi-step tasks and structured targets to measure true long-horizon performance.
method: Curate 571 long-latency tasks across real Android apps in both Chinese and English to reflect realistic user scenarios.
Annotate tasks with nested sub-targets to allow stepwise, fine-grained evaluation (sub-goal tracking + final goal success).
Provide an evaluation harness and metrics focused on long-horizon behavior (task length, sub-target completion, error propagation, success rate).
impact: Researchers and practitioners get a realistic, multilingual benchmark to stress-test planning, memory, and robustness of GUI agents, accelerating progress on agents that perform complex, multi-step mobile workflows.
visual_elements: Overview infographic: device mockup with a 26+ step timeline showing nested sub-targets branching from a main task.
Bar chart: distribution of task lengths and success rates comparing coarse vs fine-grained metrics.
Tree diagram: example task decomposed into nested sub-targets to illustrate stepwise evaluation.
Dashboard mockup: evaluation metrics panel showing sub-target completion, latency, and error propagation.
paper_title: AndroidLens: Long-latency Evaluation with Nested Sub-targets for Android GUI Agents
paper_authors: Yue Cao, Yingyao Wang, Pi Bu, Jingxuan Xing, Wei Jiang
